formal_accuser.name: maire et échevins of Neufchateau

confession.devil_appearance: belle et honneste demoiselle all in white
confession.seduction_context: When she was being persecuted by Daguenel and Drouot, who threw stones against her door, broke her window, and scattered her store of firewood. A beautiful and honest lady all in white appeared to her at night and promised to protect her.

testimony.quarrel_subject: He gave her only soup, not meat, and gave meat to his dog instead
testimony.threat_quote: tu ne m'a envoyé que la souppe et tu donne de la chair à ton chien, tu t'en repentiras

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused meat as alms because too occupied

witnesses.name: Nicolle (veuve Blaise Voiry)

witnesses.name: Demenge Hacoet

testimony.quarrel_subject: Stopped alms on Sunday because of her reputation as witch

witnesses.name: Florentin Drouot
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: she used to spin in his house

testimony.quarrel_subject: Asked by Alix not to sit on her bed; told her she was no longer welcome in house

notable_quotes.english: you only sent me soup and you give meat to your dog, you will repent of it
notable_quotes.context: After being given only soup while dog got meat

notable_quotes.french: tu donne de la chair à ton chien, tu t'en repentiras
notable_quotes.english: you give meat to your dog, you will repent of it
notable_quotes.context: After the dog became ill with twisted legs

economic_context.details: Huguette was a poor widow who received charity and alms. She relied on charitable giving from neighbors including soup, meat, and money. Multiple witnesses reference giving or refusing her alms. She was offered money by Symon Sallet to leave town but refused, stating she was 'child of the town and of good blood.' Economic vulnerability as elderly widow receiving charity appears central to her social position.

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill after being touched on shoulder; limbs twisted, making noise like dog barking, appeared near death at points
Very ill, believed bewitched, later died
harms_catalog.attributed_to: Huguette Couroyeur (suspected but she refused to help)

harms_catalog.harm_description: Ill for four months, as if bewitched and unable to move limbs
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Driving her out of house which she was haunting too often

harms_catalog.harm_description: Legs strangely twisted, had to be drowned
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Gave her only soup but gave meat to the dog

harms_catalog.harm_description: Similar illness to dog - had to go on crutches, later healed by her touch

harms_catalog.victim_name: Jean (son of Jeanne and Demengel Hacoet)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Aged 2, became ill and as if possessed, crying out profanities and fighting off anyone who approached
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused meat as alms because too occupied
Stopped alms on Sunday because of reputation as witch

harms_catalog.harm_description: Felt something prick her in bed, great misery for 4 days (later testimony: 15 days with severe pains in stomach and legs, recurring)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Asked Huguette not to sit on her bed
harms_catalog.method_alleged: curse and something left in bed

harms_catalog.harm_description: Great pain in knee, could only get about with crutches for 3 months
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Told her she was no longer welcome in his house
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: soon after she gave him 'un mauvais regard'

harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill after giving alms, only just returned to work though still not fully recovered
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Huguette called her 'une mauvaise garce' after receiving alms

Demenge Hacoet gave Huguette half-ecu for curing his son

Found in Huguette's possession during interrogation
Found in Huguette's possession during interrogation, she gave natural explanations

Huguette refused money to flee, saying she was 'child of town and of good blood'

Saints' names used in nut ceremony for healing

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: held in prison with no communication; devil allegedly visited her in prison

change_de_nancy.modification_details: Approved torture on 4 September 1609 'with moderation appropriate to her age'; approved death sentence on 17 September 1609

hearsay_chains.content: Witnessed Florentin Druot's illness and healing by Huguette
Told she was bewitched by Huguette who called her 'une mauvaise garce'

emotional_state_notes: judges suggested Devil might be obstructing her from saying more
afraid and looking one way then another when asked to help Jean Francois's wife

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Described Claude Daguenel as worthless man who wished his mother to 500,000 devils; said his illness was caused by crime against mother
Called Florentin Drouot 'ung ivrogne et ung sac a vin' (drunkard and wine sack) and 'renyeur de Dieu' (God-denier)
Said Demenge Hacoet was 'ung meschant homme et un menteur' (wicked man and liar)

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony, torture, confession and retraction, accomplice accusations, and notable procedural irregularities. The accused retracted her accusations against accomplices to priests before execution, but executioner reported she renewed them in final words. PG des Vosges ordered release of accused accomplices since no judge heard the last-minute accusation. The trial shows classic patterns of poor elderly widow accused after refusing charity or quarrels. Notable that two witnesses (Daguenel and Meurot) were present at interrogation and signed documents. Huguette's emotional distress and defense strategy of attacking witnesses' character is well documented. The healing practices using nuts with saints' names is particularly interesting cultural detail.
